metadata.title: Full-faradaic-active nitrogen species doping enables high-energy-density carbon-based supercapacitor

Table 1 Sample NTotal Pyridinic N (N-6) Pyrrolic N (N-5) Oxidized N (NO) HNPC973 21.7 10.7 8.4 2.6 HNPC1073 14.1 6.8 5.9 1.4 HNPC1173 6.2 2.3 2.6 1.3 Full-faradaic-active nitrogen species doping enables high-energy-density carbon-based supercapacitor Wei Wei a Zhangjing Chen a Yan Zhang a Jian Chen a Liu Wan a Cheng Du a Mingjiang Xie a ⁎ Xuefeng Guo b ⁎ a Hubei Key Laboratory for Processing and Application of Catalytic Materials, Huanggang Normal University, Huanggang 438000, Hubei, China Hubei Key Laboratory for Processing and Application of Catalytic Materials Huanggang Normal University Huanggang Hubei 438000 China aHubei Key Laboratory for Processing and Application of Catalytic Materials, Huanggang Normal University, Huanggang 438000, Hubei, China b Key Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, Jiangsu, China Key Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry MOE School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nanjing University Nanjing Jiangsu 210093 China bKey Lab of Mesoscopic Chemistry MOE, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, Jiangsu, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Nitrogen doping is usually adopted in carbon based supercapacitor to enhance its relatively low energy density by providing extra pseudocapacity. However, the improvement of energy density is normally limited because the content of the introduced nitrogen species is not high and meanwhile only part of them is electrochemically active. Herein, we designed and fabricated a class of hierarchical nitrogen-rich porous carbons (HNPCs) possessing not only very high nitrogen content (up to 21.7 atom%) but also fully electrochemically active nitrogen species (i.e., pyridinic N, pyrrolic N and oxidized N). Especially, in the synthesis of HNPCs, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) was used in situ not only as a nitrogen source but also as a catalyst to facilitate the polymerization of phenol and formaldehyde (as carbon precursor) and as a template to create the hierarchical porous structure. As electrodes for aqueous symmetric supercapacitor, the HNPCs with full faradaic-active nitrogen functionalities exhibit excellent supercapacitor performance: high energy density of 36.8 Wh/kg at 2.0 kW/kg (maintaining 25.7 Wh/kg at 38 kW/kg), superior rate capability with 78% capacitance retention from 1.0 to 20 A/g and excellent cycling stability with over 95% capacitance retention after 10 000 cycles, indicating their promising application potential in electrochemical energy storage. This novel carbon material with high-content and full electrochemically active nitrogen species may find extensive potential applications in the energy storage/conversion, catalysis, adsorption, and so on. Graphical abstract Full-faradaic-active nitrogen doped nanocarbon fabricated by adopting graphitic carbon nitride as catalyst, template and nitrogen sources exhibits excellent supercapacitor performance with ultrahigh energy density of 36.8 Wh/kg at 2.0 kW/kg (maintaining 25.7 Wh/kg at 38 kW/kg). Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nanocarbon g-C3N4 Catalyst/template Nitrogen doping Aqueous supercapacitor 1 Introduction In the field of electrochemical energy storage that involves ultrafast and long-time charge/discharge processes, supercapacitors (SCs) have been considered promising towards practical applications [1–6]. Generally, the SCs possess low energy density compared to secondary batteries [7–9] resulted from low capacity and narrow working voltage, which restricts their applications when a large energy density is required. According to the formula of energy density, E = 1/2CV 2, the energy density of SCs can be raised by increasing the capacity (C) and/or enhancing the working voltage (V). Usually, a relatively high working voltage can be achieved in non-aqueous electrolytes (including organic and ionic liquid electrolytes), thus delivering energy density higher than those of aqueous electrolytes [10,11]. Nonetheless, compared to working in non-aqueous electrolytes, much higher power densities can be achieved when a capacitor is working in aqueous electrolytes. It is because the ionic conductivities of aqueous electrolytes are 20 to 50 times the ionic diffusivity of organic electrolytes. In this regard, developing high-energy-density SCs to work with aqueous electrolytes is a wise choice to cater for the requirement of high energy density while without losing the unique feature of high power density. Since the operating voltage of aqueous electrolytes is limited due to the narrow electrochemical stability window (1.25 V) [12–14], developing electrode material of high capacity would be the way to increase the energy density of SCs in aqueous electrolytes. Among electrode materials of SCs, porous carbons with rigid microstructures exhibit the best cycling performance in charge-discharge processes [15–18]. Furthermore, the unique features of carbon materials such as low cost, chemical inertness, large specific surface area, and adjustable pore size make them promising candidates for SCs. However, the low energy density of electric double layer capacitance (EDLC) and narrow operating voltage windows in aqueous electrolytes hinder the practical use of carbon-based supercapacitors in energy storage devices, which requires large energy density as well as fast charge/discharge response. As a result, developing high-performance carbon-based electrode materials with improved energy density while maintaining high power density have long been a hot research topic [19–21]. It has been reckoned that by increasing extra pseudocapacity via reversible Faradaic reaction between electrolytes and heteroatomic functionalities is an efficient way to enhance the energy density of carbon-based electrodes [22–25]. Among the functionalized carbon materials, the nitrogen-doped ones with electrochemically active nitrogen species are intensively investigated. This type of carbons can be easily obtained by simple carbonization of nitrogen-rich precursors. However, the nitrogen content in the final carbon products is usually low (usually below 9%) because of the instability of nitrogen-containing precursors during carbonization process at high temperature [26,27]. Furthermore, in most reported nitrogen doped carbons, the introduced nitrogen species are usually not full-electrochemically-active. As a result, the energy density of these carbon-based electrodes in aqueous electrolytes remains relatively low (usually around 10 Wh/kg) [28]. Another key factor that can influence the performance of SCs is the porosity of electrode materials because it governs the diffusion conductivity of electrolytes. For the development of SCs, it is hence necessary to find methods for facile synthesis of carbon materials that are high in nitrogen contain and rich in porosity. To the best of our knowledge, there are few reports on the fabrication of carbon materials doped with full-faradaic active nitrogen species to date. Thus, it is challenging to obtain a full-faradaic active nitrogen species functionalized nanocarbons. Herein, we report for the first time a facile approach for the synthesis of hierarchical nitrogen-doped porous carbons (HNPCs) with high-content and full electrochemically-active nitrogen species from phenol and formaldehyde using g-C3N4 as catalyst, template and nitrogen source (as shown in Fig. 1 ). The g-C3N4 firstly catalyzes the polymerization of phenol and formaldehyde at low temperature, then decomposes and produces nitrogen-containing gasses at ca. 973 K, meanwhile serves as a template to create the hierarchical porous structure, thus eliminating the need of extra nitrogen sources and post-synthetic removal of template. It was demonstrated that HNPCs with controlled composition could be facilely obtained by adjusting the carbonization temperature. The optimized HNPC has a very high nitrogen content of 21.7 atom% which is homogeneously distributed throughout the material. Importantly, benefited from the contribution of the rich electrochemically active nitrogen functionalities, the HNPC obtained at a carbonization temperature of 973 K displays a ultrahigh energy density of 36.8 Wh/kg at 2.0 kW/kg, maintaining 25.7 Wh/kg at a high power density of 38 kW/kg, which is about two times those of the most recently reported results in the literature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of HNPCs Typically, 0.94 g of phenol and 3.0 mL (37 wt.%) of formaldehyde were homogenously dissolved in 10.0 mL of distilled water. The obtained solution was then mixed with g-C3N4 (detail of g-C3N4 synthesis is available in supporting information, SI) at room temperature to undergo in situ polymerization of phenol and formaldehyde for 48 h. The as-derived g-C3N4@phenolic resin was then dried at 373 K for 24 h. Finally HNPCs were obtained by carbonization of the g-C3N4@phenolic resin at 973, 1073, and 1173 K for 2 h under Ar. The as-obtained samples are denoted herein as HNPC973, HNPC1073 and HNPC1173, respectively. 2.2 Characterizations The morphology and microstructure of samples were analyzed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Carl Zeiss Sigma 300) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL 2100F). The crystallinity was characterized by X-ray diffraction (SHIMADZU XRD-6100) and Raman spectroscopy (Horiba Scientific LabRAM HR Evolution). The textual parameters were obtained by nitrogen sorption isotherms (Micromeritics ASAP2020) at liquid nitrogen temperature and the pore size distribution curves were calculated by BJH method using the adsorption branches. The surface compositions were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250XI). Thermogravimetric and Differential Scanning Calorimetry analysis (TG-DTA) was recorded on NETZSCH STA 449 C under nitrogen conditions with the heating rate of 10 K/min. 2.3 Symmetric supercapacitor performance test Electrochemical energy storage performance was evaluated by a symmetric two-electrode configuration over a CHI660E work station. Typically, the working electrode was fabricated by a standard procedure involving first coating a current collector of nickel foam with a mixture of HNPC (active material, 80 wt.%), acetylene black (conductive agent, 10 wt.%) and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE, binder, 10 wt.%) which was then subject to pressing of just under 10 MPa. The positive and negative electrode with the same content of active material (areal loading amount of ~2.8 mg/cm2) was immersed in 1.0 M Na2SO4 to form the symmetric supercapacitor cell. The SCs performance was investigated by cyclic voltammograms (CVs), galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD), and AC impedance spectroscopy. The capacity of the cell was calculated from the GCD plots according the formula of C s = 2 × I Δ t m Δ V (F/g), where I is the current density (A/g), m is the mass of active material in a single electrode, Δt is the discharge time (s) and ΔV is the discharge voltage window (V). The energy densities and power densities of the cells were calculated according to the formula of E = 1 8 × 1 3.6 × C s V 2 (Wh/kg) and P = E t (W/kg), respectively, where C s (F/g) is the capacitance of the single electrode, V (V) is the working voltage of the cell, t is the discharge time. Galvanostatic charge/discharge tests of 10 000 cycles were performed using a battery test system (LAND CT2001A). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and microstructure of HNPCs The SEM image of the as-synthesized g-C3N4 reveals that the g-C3N4 surface is rough (Fig. S1 in supporting information). With rich alkaline sites (e.g. pyridine N), g-C3N4 can catalyze the polymerization of phenol and formaldehyde to form a g-C3N4@phenolic resin. The TG-DTA curves of g-C3N4 (Fig. S2a) and g-C3N4@phenolic resin (Fig. S2b) both show a sharp exothermic peak accompanied with significant weight loss at around 974 and 965 K, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of g-C3N4. Judging from the TG-DTA curves, the total weight loss is ~100% for g-C3N4 and ~82% for g-C3N4@phenolic resin, respectively. For g-C3N4, the weight loss of near 100% can be attributed to the completely decomposition of g-C3N4 at high temperature, whereas for the g-C3N4@phenolic resin, the partial weight loss of 82% can be ascribed to the residual carbon from phenolic resin, which verifies the formation of phenolic resin catalyzed by g-C3N4. After carbonization above 970 K, HNPCs could be obtained as a result of g-C3N4 gasification. The typical TEM images of HNPC973 are shown in Fig. 2 . The TEM images (Fig. 2a–c) taken at different magnifications show that the HNPC973 has a porous foam-like microstructure. The high-resolution TEM image (Fig. 2d) reveals disordered lattice fringes of graphitic crystallite. The SEM images of HNPC973, HNPC1073, and HNPC1173 are shown in Fig. 3 . In agreement with the TEM results, they all have a foam-like morphology with hierarchical porous structure. The generation of foam-like morphology can be attributed to the gasification of g-C3N4. The decomposition of g-C3N4 during carbonization generates a large amount of nitrogen-containing gasses, leading to the formation of the hierarchical porous structure. In other words, g-C3N4 also serves as template for the construction of the foam skeleton. The corresponding elemental mappings of the three HNPCs reveal homogeneous distribution of C, N, and O atoms, confirming successful creation of nitrogen functionalities in the HNPCs using the g-C3N4 in situ templating method. The crystallinity of HNPCs was investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Raman spectroscopy. The XRD patterns (Fig. S3) display a broad diffraction peak at around 26° and a weak peak at around 44°, which can be respectively indexed to the (002) and (101) diffraction of graphite [29], revealing a certain graphitization degree of HNPCs. The broad diffraction peaks imply poor crystallinity, which is consistent with the HRTEM result of Fig. 2(d). With the increase of carbonization temperature from 973 to 1173 K, the (002) peak slightly increases in intensity, suggesting that the increase of carbonization temperature results in higher degree of graphitization. The Raman spectra (Fig. S4) of the HNPCs show two peaks at ca. 1350 cm−1 (D-band) and 1560 cm−1 (G-band) which are characteristic of carbon materials. The former corresponds to defects within the carbon lattice while the latter symmetry vibration mode of graphite. A higher intensity ratio of G peak to D peak (I G/I D) means higher graphitization degree of carbon materials [29]. The I G/I D of Fig. S4 is 0.82 for HNPC973, 0.93 for HNPC1073 and 0.98 for HNPC1173. The data indicate that the increase of carbonization temperature would lead to higher quality of graphitization, in agreement with the XRD results. The textual properties of HNPCs were analyzed by nitrogen sorption isotherms (Fig. 4 ). The HNPCs display IV-type curves with a small hysteresis loop, indicative of porous structure (Fig. 4a). The corresponding textual parameters are listed in Table S1. The specific surface area and total volume are 570 m2/g and 0.92 cm3/g for HNPC973; 414 m2/g and 0.46 cm3/g for HNPC1073, and 549 m2/g and 0.69 cm3/g for HNPC1173, respectively. As Table S1 shown, the SSA decreased from 570 to 414 m2/g and then increased to 549 m2/g with the increase of carbonization temperature from 973 to 1173 K mainly due to the variation of microporosity. Obviously, the ratio of external surface area to total surface area (S Exter/S Total) decreases from 53.3% to 52.6% and then to 36.1% as the carbonization temperature is raised from 973 to 1073 K and then to 1173 K, respectively, indicating diminution of external surface area upon high temperature carbonization. The pore size distribution (PSD) curves (Fig. 4b) are bimodal, showing pores of ca. 3.87 and 43 nm. The former is plausible due to the dehydrogenation and deoxygenation of phenolic resin, while the latter due to the gasification of g-C3N4 upon high temperature carbonization. 3.2 Surface chemistry of HNPCs The surface nature of HNPCs was examined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 5 and Table S2, the HNPCs are composed of carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and oxygen (O). For HNPC973, it is 75.2 atom% (C), 3.1 atom% (O) and 21.7 atom% (N). Judging from the data of Table S2, it is apparent that with the increase of carbonization temperature, the surface content of C increases, while that of N and O decreases, implying increase of graphitic quality but loss of nitrogen and oxygen functionalities. The HNPC973 owns the highest nitrogen content of 21.7 atom% in comparison with 14.1 atom% of HNPC1073 and 6.2 atom% of HNPC1173. To identify the nitrogen species in HNPCs, the N1s profiles were subject to deconvolution as shown in Fig. 5(b–d). The N 1 s spectra exhibit three fitted peaks at binding energy of around 398, 400 and 402 eV, assignable to pyridinic N (N-6), pyrrolic N (N-5), and oxidized N (NO), respectively [30,31]. The relative contents of these nitrogen species are listed in Table 1 . The detailed contents of every N species are 10.7 atom% (N-6), 8.4 atom% (N-5) and 2.6 atom% (NO) for HNPC973; 6.8 atom% (N-6), 5.9 atom% (N-5) and 1.4 atom% (NO) for HNPC1073; 2.3 atom% (N-6), 2.6 atom% (N-5) and 1.3 atom% (NO) for HNPC1173, respectively. The deconvoluted C 1 s XPS spectra exhibit four fitted peaks at binding energy of around 284.6, 285.2, 286 and 289 eV, index to −C=C− (sp 2), −C−N−C− (N-5), −C=N− (N-6), and −C=N−O− (NO), respectively, which further confirms the nitrogen species in the HNPCs. Interestingly, although the prepared HNPCs have a certain graphitization degree, the XPS analysis results show that there is no graphitic N species existing in the HNPCs. As the synthesis schematic shown (Fig. 1), the absence of graphitic N species may be attributed to the unique synthesis method, which introducing the nitrogen functionalities by grafting the gaseous fragments of decomposed g-C3N4 onto the surface of phenolic resin-derived carbon substrate. Particularly, the nitrogen species existed in HNPCs were all reported to be electrochemical active in aqueous electrolyte. (1) (2) (3) These nitrogen species can provide Faradaic pseudocapacitance [31–33] by reversible Faradaic reaction equations (as shown in Eqs. 1‒3), thus a superior supercapacitor performances of HNPCs based electrodes can be expected. 3.3 Symmetric supercapacitor performance of HNPCs To evaluate the performance of HNPCs, supercapacitors of symmetric type were assembled in aqueous electrolytes of 1.0 M Na2SO4, which could enable a higher working voltage (~2.0 V) than others aqueous electrolytes. The SCs performances were examined using cyclic voltammetry and galvanostatic charge/discharge techniques. To find out the optimal working voltage for the symmetric cell, cyclic voltammograms (CV) at various voltagewindows were recorded as shown in Figs. S6–S8. The CV plots of electrodes based on HNPC973, HNPC1073 and HNPC1173 measured at a scan rate of 10 mV/s reveal an optimal working voltage of 2.0 V in the aqueous electrolyte. The CV plots of HNPC973 (Fig. 6 a), HNPC1073 (Fig. S9a) and HNPC973 (Fig. S10a) at different scan rates all show rectangular patterns of irregular shape, implying the co-existence of electric double layer capacitance (EDLC) and pseudocapacitance behaviors. Similar to a previous report on nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon electrode [34], there is no obvious redox peak in the CV plots of the HNPC-based electrodes. It is because the co-existence of three types of nitrogen species leads to multiple faradaic peaks, thus resulting in near rectangular EDLC-like CV curves. The GCD curves of HNPC973 (Fig. 6b), HNPC1073 (Fig. S9b) and HNPC1173 (Fig. S10b) all display a distorted triangular-shaped pattern, further confirming the co-existence of EDLC and pseudocapacitance. The capacities including gravimetric and volumetric capacitance [35,36] of the HNPC-based electrodes were calculated from the GCD curves and are shown in Fig. 6(c). Obviously, the HNPC973-based electrode achieves a capacity higher than that of HNPC1073 and HNPC1173 at each current density. The maximum capacity of the HNPC973-based electrode is as high as 265 F/g (185 F/cm3) at a current density of 1.0 A/g (Coulombic efficiency of 93.5%), and a capacity of 206 F/g (144 F/cm3) can be maintained at a much larger current density of 20 A/g (Coulombic efficiency of 100%), exhibiting superior capacity retention of 78%. The low Coulombic efficiency at low current density can be attributed to the existence of irreversible Faradaic reaction of the surface functionalities with electrolyte. For the HNPC1073-based and HNPC1173-based electrodes at a current density of 1.0 A/g, the maximum capacity is 186 F/g (193 F/cm3) and 148 F/g (124 F/cm3), respectively. From 1 to 20 A/g, the capacity retention is 68% for HNPC1073 and 73% for HNPC1173. The larger capacity and better capacity retention of HNPC973 in comparison to those of HNPC1073 and HNPC1173 may be a collaborative outcome of high nitrogen content (21.7 atom% vs. 14.1 atom% and 6.2 atom%) and large surface area (570 m2/g vs. 414 m2/g and 549 m2/g) of HNPC973, because an increase of the two factors would lead to EDLC and pseudocapacity enhancement. Moreover, a large content of nitrogen functionalities would mean enhancement of wettability of electrode materials, and with effective contact between electrode and electrolyte, there is reduced interface resistance and fast EDLC formation. To investigate the capacitive behavior of the HNPC-based electrodes, electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were acquired. The Nyquist plots of the three electrodes display near vertical patterns in the low frequency region (Fig. S11), indicating good capacitive response and low ion transfer resistance. In high frequency region, the HNPC973 electrode exhibits a small equivalent series resistance (ESR) semicycle of 3.5 Ω, suggesting small interfacial resistance [37]. The performance of the fabricated symmetric supercapacitors for electrochemical energy storage can also be reflected by the plot of energy density versus power density. As shown in the Ragone plots of Fig. 6(d), the maximum energy density of the HNPC973-based electrode is as high as 36.8 Wh/kg at 2.0 kW/kg. Even at an ultrahigh power density of 38 kW/kg the energy density can be maintained at 25.7 Wh/kg. In contrast, the maximum energy density at 2.0 kW/kg is 25.8 Wh/kg for HNPC1073 and 20.5 Wh/kg for HNPC1173. A comparison was made between the recently reported carbon-based aqueous symmetric supercapacitor and the HNPC973-based supercapacitor (Fig. 7 ). Obviously, the HNPC973-based electrode exhibits energy densities higher than those of recently reported carbon-based electrodes in terms of equal power density [38–47], evidencing the superiority of the HNPC973-based symmetric supercapacitor. Furthermore, in a test of continual charge/discharge at 10 A/g, the fabricated symmetric supercapacitor device shows outstanding stability (Fig. 8 ), showing up to 95% retention after 10 000 cycles. The excellent supercapacitor performance including ultrahigh energy density, high capacity retention, long charge/discharge stability of HNPC973 can be ascribed to its high electroactive nitrogen content (21.7 atom%), openly accessible surface and rigid skeleton. Endowed with abundant redox sites, super cycling stability and stable microstructure, HNPC973 shows great potential for high-performance supercapacitors. 4 Conclusions For the first time, a versatile approach adopting graphitic carbon nitride as catalyst, template and nitrogen sources was applied for the fabrication of hierarchical nitrogen-rich porous carbons (HNPCs) that are high in nitrogen content (up to 21.7 atom%) and homogenous in nitrogen distribution. Remarkably, the nitrogen species are all electrochemically active nitrogen species for Faradaic pseudocapacitance (pyridinic N, pyrrolic N and oxidized N), because of the special nitrogen source of the gaseous fragments of decomposed g-C3N4. As electrode material for aqueous symmetric supercapacitor, HNPC973 exhibits excellent performance with an ultrahigh energy density of 36.8 Wh/kg at 2.0 kW/kg (maintaining 25.7 Wh/kg at 38 kW/kg), superior capacitance retention of 78%, and excellent stability with over 95% capacitance retention after continual charge/discharge of 10 000 cycles at large current density of 10.0 A/g. The HNPC973 material with 21.7 atom% nitrogen (in which 88% are pyridinic N and pyrrolic N) content presents promising application potential in electrochemical energy storage as well as in the fields such as energy conversion, catalysis, sorption, and many others. coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen doping is usually adopted in carbon based supercapacitor to enhance its relatively low energy density by providing extra pseudocapacity. However, the improvement of energy density is normally limited because the content of the introduced nitrogen species is not high and meanwhile only part of them is electrochemically active. Herein, we designed and fabricated a class of hierarchical nitrogen-rich porous carbons (HNPCs) possessing not only very high nitrogen content (up to 21.7 atom%) but also fully electrochemically active nitrogen species (i.e., pyridinic N, pyrrolic N and oxidized N). Especially, in the synthesis of HNPCs, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) was used in situ not only as a nitrogen source but also as a catalyst to facilitate the polymerization of phenol and formaldehyde (as carbon precursor) and as a template to create the hierarchical porous structure. As electrodes for aqueous symmetric supercapacitor, the HNPCs with full faradaic-active nitrogen functionalities exhibit excellent supercapacitor performance: high energy density of 36.8 Wh/kg at 2.0 kW/kg (maintaining 25.7 Wh/kg at 38 kW/kg), superior rate capability with 78% capacitance retention from 1.0 to 20 A/g and excellent cycling stability with over 95% capacitance retention after 10 000 cycles, indicating their promising application potential in electrochemical energy storage. This novel carbon material with high-content and full electrochemically active nitrogen species may find extensive potential applications in the energy storage/conversion, catalysis, adsorption, and so on.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V. and Science Press.
coredata.dc:title: Full-faradaic-active nitrogen species doping enables high-energy-density carbon-based supercapacitor
